awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Balancing the Portfolio: Efficiency and Productivity of Federal Biomedical R&D Funding
awd_abstract_narration:
This cross-disciplinary, cross-institution collaborative research project combines economic analysis with state-of-the-art methods from statistical machine learning, to assess the relative efficiency and efficacy of research and development expenditures across the U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) portfolio of extramural projects. The novel combination of econometrics, topic modeling, and document classification permits analysis of massive collections of grant abstracts and scientific publications, identification of latent research topics present in NIH-funded research, assessment of possible spillover effects across research topics, and evaluation of causal linkages between changes in NIH funding by research topic and scientific advances. Two specific research outcomes are considered: scientific publications, classified by topic; and pharmaceutical innovation, measured by drugs entering into clinical development to treat specific diseases.  Planned research also includes refinement of existing economic theory to produce normative evaluations of the allocation of public research spending.

Broader Impacts: This research will inform key policy questions related to federal funding of biomedical research. First, fiscal austerity requires careful attention to the nation's research portfolio and investments. This project will describe and evaluate the productivity of those investments, as a first step towards policy recommendations for rebalancing the portfolio, to maximize society's expected return on investment. Second, if NIH funding for basic research spurs increased pharmaceutical innovation, NIH possesses an important policy tool to promote pharmaceutical R&D in areas of high therapeutic importance or significant health disparity.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) invest over $30 billion each year in scientific research and development, with the aim of improving population health and reducing the burden of disease. Understanding and evaluating outcomes across such an extensive and varied portfolio of investments requires new methods to quantify funding allocations across topics, and to identify resulting advances in foundational scientific knowledge.

This collaborative research project investigated usefulness of statistical text mining techniques to automatically extract information about changes in funding allocations and resulting publication outcomes across research topics. Our specific case-study included data on approximately 150,000 research grants funded by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) between 1994 and 2013. Each record in this database includes the text of the grant title and abstract, the amount of funding awarded, a list of publications arising from the grant-funded research, as well as technical information about how the funding was awarded. A subset of these records, from 2008 onwards, also includes Research, Condition, and Disease Categorization (RCDC) standardized tags assigned by the NIH. Examples of RCDC categories include specific diseases and conditions (for example, Breast Cancer), as well as general research types (for example, Clinical Trials).

Statistical text mining algorithms developed as part of this research collaboration used the subset of NCI grants already tagged by NIH to learn a statistical model that could evaluate the extent to which any given text document is associated with any of 88 different RCDC categories. This model was applied to estimate the probability that each of the approximately 150,000 NCI research grants belonged to each RCDC category. The same model was then also applied to approximately 200,000 abstracts from scientific research articles published in related fields over the same 20-year period, including articles describing NCI-funded research as well as articles describing research funded by other, non-NIH sources.

The analytic dataset generated by this project allows economists and public policy analysts to investigate and predict how changes in cancer research funding levels and mechanisms may affect the quantity and quality or usefulness of published scientific research advances. More broadly, this project also promoted greater crossdisciplinary understanding of the requirements and current limitations of applied computational methods for social science and policy research, and supported continuing professional development bridging across scientific disciplines.
